Unnamed: 10: FY22 investment was elevated due to extra support we provided to communities through our NRMA COVID-19 Relief Program and NRMA HELP package.
Increase driven by IAG Resilience Day in which over 3,000 IAG employees volunteered across 140 events to deliver community resilience actions.
Driven by the increase in fuel consumption and the opening of Repairhub sites in New Zealand.
Primarily the result of lower emissions factors for Australian states (notably QLD, NSW, and VIC).
Increase in business travel, notably air travel, with COVID-19-related restrictions no longer in place in FY23.

Increased fuel usage as there were no COVID-19 related restrictions in place in FY23.
No material change in the number, or capacity, of chillers at IAG sites.

Unnamed: 1: Natural gas / Stationary Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG)
Unnamed: 10: Increase driven by stationary LPG usage with the opening of additional Repairhub sites in New Zealand.
Reduction in Australian state emissions factors sourced from NGER (National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting) as state grids steadily decarbonise.
Reduction driven by a lower, up to date print paper emissions factor. Previous factor had not been updated since publication in 2013.

Unnamed: 1: 3. Fuel-and-energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2)
Unnamed: 10: Driven by transmission & distribution losses: emissions factor increased in FY23 in line with an increase in the use of imported fuel in the region.
Higher waste volumes driven by the opening of Repairhub sites (higher waste relative to office-based sites) and an increase in office occupancy.
Material increase in air travel (though still roughly half the pre-COVID-19 levels) with COVID-related restrictions no longer in place in FY23.
Reduction in WFH emissions driven by lower electricity emissions factors and a methodology update to account for employee annual leave.

Unnamed: 1: 12. End of life treatment of sold products
1. A female Director - Wendy Thorpe - was appointed on 23 March 2023, effective 1 July 2023. The percentage of women on the Board at 21 August 2023 is 27%.
2. Scope 1: direct emissions from owned and controlled sources.

3. Scope 2: indirect emissions from the generation of purchased energy. We use a location-based approach, which reflects the average emissions intensity of the grids on which our energy consumption occurs.

4. Scope 3: indirect emissions that occur upstream and downstream of our business. IAG includes the following scope 3 emission sources within the boundary of reporting: business travel, waste to landfill, paper, staff working from home, and  transmission & distribution (T&D) losses (which includes T&D losses from electricity, natural gas, stationary LPG, and company vehicle fuel sources).
5. Measured Scope 3 emissions categorisation informed by the Greenhouse Gas Protocol.
6. Working from home (WFH) emissions added to the scope of our measured Scope 3 emissions in FY22.
